Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Why Media Collaboration Flourishes Despite Interreligious Conflict

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientists have long tried to understand the conditions that are necessary to produce mutual tolerance and understanding within contexts where different groups of people practice highly varied religions. Within these debates, there is a school of thought that suggests that certain kinds of religious interactions are likely to give rise to conflict, and there is another that suggests that some religions tend to be more malleable and adopt ideas from a range of different secular and religious practices. It is often claimed that there are certain religions make their practitioners less inclined to cooperate with individuals outside their religion. This research, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous empirical fieldwork, examines a case where individuals from religions that have historically been in conflict with one another engage collaboratively to produce media in which cultural and religious differences are a major theme. The project asks what circumstances and relationships give rise to these kinds of collaboration.

Mr. Brian Smithson under the supervision of Dr. Charles Piot of Duke University will investigate the strategies human beings use to overcome religious and international tensions in order to accomplish collaborative endeavors. He will pursue this inquiry by exploring media production along the border of BÃ©nin and Nigeria. This is an ideal context within which to investigate this question for several reasons: there are vast cultural and religious differences within a relatively small geographic space, as participants practice three different religions; the participants are highly variable in their media expertise, suggesting that collaborative media production is voluntaristic, rather than driven by mutual economic or logistical benefit. The project will test theories in the social sciences that assume that religious interactions necessarily give rise to religious clashes or religious hybridization. Classic ethnographic data collection methods, including participant observation and interviews with various stakeholders in media production will be used. This project will explore what roles national identity, religious affiliation, and professional prestige play in negotiations over religious attitudes and conceptions of community, as well as what methods of media production allow for a broader debate about religious content, iconography, and aesthetics in media. The findings of this study promise to benefit policymakers as they struggle with increasing religious tensions in their countries and fears that inter-religious strife may spill across borders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Brian C. Smithson completed research for his dissertation, "Piety in Progress: Video Filmmaking and Religious Encounter in Bénin," with the support of the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. A cultural anthropologist, Brian conducted twenty months of field research in the West African country of Bénin. There, he joined a non-profit association of filmmakers called CAPADI, whose members specialize in producing video movies in the Yorùbá language. They then sell these films directly to home viewers in towns and villages near the Nigerian border. Brian's research focused on how the moviemaking process brings together people from diverse religious backgrounds—Christians, Muslims, and followers of indigenous African religions—and gives them a forum to interact with one another, debate questions of religious and cultural concern, and maintain mutual tolerance for one another's religious practices.

To answer his research questions, Brian became an apprentice actor and film producer. In this capacity, he worked alongside Beninese movie professionals and observed their filmmaking processes firsthand at all stages: story writing, casting, shooting, editing, marketing, and sales. This behind-the-scenes access allowed Brian to witness and analyze the debates and conflicts filmmakers faced due to the religious diversity of the film crews, but also the strategies they used to resolve those disputes peacefully. This insider's perspective also allowed Brian to assess how these disagreements influenced the final form of the movies the crews produced together. Brian supplemented this direct participation and observation by conducing dozens of interviews with video film producers in both Bénin and Nigeria. He also attended religious ceremonies, festivals, and services at local churches, mosques, and temples alongside members of the community. His fieldwork culminated in Brian producing his own video film in collaboration with the Yorùbá filmmakers' association. This last experience proved invaluable, as Brian's role as producer gave him complete access to all phases of the movie's production, allowing him to see the disputes that arose and how the filmmakers handled them. He is currently translating the video film into English, at which point he will offer it for streaming on the Internet free of charge.

Brian is now writing his doctoral dissertation at Duke University in Durham, North Carolina. His experiences living and working in Bénin provided the essential data needed to understand how collaborative filmmaking by members of different religions gives them a way to debate religious differences, but also compels them to reach peaceful agreements. Major factors that influence these creators to resolve their differences without violence include their mutual goal to finish each film project and make a profit from it, but also the fact that these creators want to improve Bénin's capacity to make high-quality films more generally. Brian's dissertation also analyzes how this type of dispute resolution reaches beyond the sites of production when members of the community watch the shooting of films in open sets and when they watch movies at home. Thus, by simply making movies with religiously diverse crews, filmmakers have the potential to influence their fans, the community more broadly, and anywhere else their finished films travel.

Brian's research efforts have already reached beyond the small community in which he worked. During his time in Bénin, he also traveled to the Pan-African Film Festival (FESPACO) in Burkina Faso and to film sets in Nigeria, where he was able to share his findings with African filmmakers from across the continent.
